I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the 2005 Country Programming Mission, the People’s Republic of China (PRC) 
asked the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide a fast-response facility to support policy 
development in priority areas of the current Eleventh Five-Year Plan (11thFYP – 2006 to 2010) 
and the PRC’s country strategy and program (CSP).1 In response, ADB included a technical 
assistance  (TA)  project  in  the  2006  TA  pipeline.  A  Fact-Finding  Mission2 was  fielded  in 
December 2005, and reached an agreement with the Ministry of Finance (MOF) and  other 
concerned  Government  agencies  on  the  impact,  outcome,  outputs,  implementation 
arrangements,  cost,  financing  arrangements,  and  terms  of  reference.3 The  design  and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The 11th FYP sets out a number of key priorities: 
 
(i)  Transform the economic growth model, aiming to conserve resources and protect 
the environment. Recycling will be encouraged to reduce constraints from limited 
land, fresh water, energy, and mine resources. The legal and policy framework 
will  be  strengthened  to  promote  clean  production.  Environmental  protection 
efforts will be enhanced to reduce air and water pollution, soil erosion, and 
desertification. 
 
(ii)  Adjust  and  improve  industry  structure.  Important  areas  relevant  to  ADB 
operations include strengthening of  the intellectual property protection system; 
creating an enabling environment for investment; promoting the development of 
service industries, such as finance, insurance, logistics, information, and legal 
services; and develop a stable, economic, and clean energy supply system. 
 
(iii)  Establish  a  socialistic  countryside  through  rural  development.  An  area  of 
emphasis is public services, which  includes (a) establishing free compulsory 
education;  (b)  establishing  a  basic  public  health  system  and  new  Rural 
Cooperative Medicare System; (c) expanding the use of biogas, and exploring 
the use of suitable clean energy in rural areas; (d) enhancing vocational training 
for rural labor; and (e) addressing rural poverty, including establishing a new rural 
social safety net. 
 
(iv)  Promote coordinated development of the different regions. The PRC will continue 
to  develop  the  western  region,  re-energize  the  northeastern  industry  base, 
facilitate the rise of the middle region, and encourage continued development of 
eastern region.  In addition, a  healthy and balanced urbanization process is 
critical to regional development. 
 
(v)  Deepen legal and governance reform. Legal reform is the basis for governance 
reform in the areas of the administrative system, tax system, financial system, 
private sector development, and market economy.

3.  More specifically, the 11th FYP sets targets in certain key areas: (i) doubling the 2001 
gross domestic product (GDP) by 2010; (ii) enhancing energy efficiency and reducing unit GDP 
energy consumption by 20% of the 2005 level; (iii) controlling environmental deterioration; and 
(iv)  implementing  free  9-year  compulsory  education,  creating  employment  opportunities, 
improving social security system, and reducing poverty. 
 
4.  The challenge now for the Government is to address the aforenoted priorities and meet 
the targets during implementation of the 11th FYP over the next five years. To do so, the 
Government will need to formulate policies and undertake reforms in a wide range of areas. The 
Government is therefore seeking TA from ADB that will be flexible to address wide-ranging 
policy development requirements and do so in a timely manner. 
 
5.  In response, this TA proposes a flexible mechanism to undertake a number of discreet 
and  focused  interventions  to  address  specific  policy  development  and  capacity  building 
requirements that will arise from time-to-time during implementation of the 11th FYP. This TA will 
adopt a similar approach to TA 4365 (Facility for Policy Reform Support), which successfully 
provided timely assistance to the Government in addressing urgent issues and disseminating 
outputs to the public and policy makers. 4 TA4365 has financed 10 components, including 
private  sector  study,  budget  law  amendment,  corporate  pension,  housing  finance,  and 
environment impact assessment. The outputs of the private sector study were transformed into 
the top proposal by the China Political Consultation Commission to the National People’s 
Congress in March 2005. The amended budget law, which has gone through public consultation, 
is  expected  to  be  submitted  to  the  National  People’s  Congress.  The  corporate  pension 
component suggested revisions to the two interim regulations on the management of the 
corporate pension system and corporate pension fund, which the Ministry of Labor and Social 
Security is reviewing. The housing finance conference brought together recommendations of 
domestic and international experts, which are being integrated into the practices of the China 
Development  Bank.  The  environment  impact  assessment  component  has  enabled  the 
dissemination of ADB’sE  nvironment Impact Assessment (2003) in the PRC, as well as the 
training of core staff in all provincial environment appraisal centers. The outputs were widely 
disseminated through publications and internet. 
 
6.  The discreet components under TA 4365 addressed in  a timely manner  the urgent 
demands of the implementing agencies (IAs). In addition, they supported reforms that were not 
provided for in the TA pipeline. The components were selected in close coordination with MOF 
and PRCM based on a set of criteria identified in the TA.5 The candidate IAs proposed their 
design,  while  PRCM  or  designated  ADB  divisions  closely  monitored  their  implementation. 
Several lessons can be drawn: (i) ADB adds considerable value by providing such selective 
small-scale,  short-term  assistance  to  complement  its  long-term  and  systematic  efforts  in 
selected strategic areas; (ii) quick and timely response can enable early involvement in policy 
formulation; and (iii) capacity building needs to be included to address challenges arising from 
the Government’s evolving policies and procedures, as well as ADB’s strategic requirements. 
The proposed TA is expected to build on these lessons to provide a flexible mechanism that can 
respond quickly to the needs of the Government.

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The objective of the TA is to provide quick, timely and quality support for reforms and 
capacity building in the priority areas of the 11FYP as they arise, as well as the ADB’s strategic 
focus areas in the PRC. Three TA outputs in ADB’s strategic areas, as well as the Government 
reform agenda, have been identified (see Appendix 3 for details).  
 
(i)  Local government debt. This is the first phase of a study on local government 
debt with implications on governance and risk management of local governments. 
The study will compile information on local government debt management in 
selected market economies, including (a) laws and regulations, (b) budgeting, (c) 
accounting and reporting system, (d) information system, and (e) early warning 
mechanisms.  Best  practices  and  lessons  of  relevant  countries  will  be 
summarized and evaluated. Preliminary recommendations will be made on the 
legal  framework  and  other  issues, including fiscal transfer and delegation of 
duties  from  central  to  local  governments,  authority  and  power  of  local 
governments  in  determining  local  taxes,  and  decision  making  and  approval 
procedures  for  the  local  governments’  budge.t  (ADB  Financing:  $100,000; 
Consulting Services: 5 person-months; Time Frame: August 2006–March 2007) 
 
(ii)  Portfolio management. The component will produce a study on effective project 
implementation that addresses coordination and harmonization of processes and 
procedures in EAs and IAs. It also will identify how to coordinate and harmonize 
the Government’s project cycle most effectively  with ADB’s project processing 
and approval processes, as well as implementation procedures. In addition, the 
study will include approaches to effective and up-front capacity building of new 
EAs and IAs. The outcome also will include a comparative analysis of portfolio 
performance of projects financed by other external funding agencies in the PRC, 
and  approaches  to  monitor  whether  ADB’s  portfolio  has  been  contributing 
effectively to the CSP outcomes and country development. Finally, it will include 
discussions on necessary corrective actions for achieving better results. (ADB 
Financing: $50,000; Consulting Services: 5 person-months; Time Frame: June–
December 2006) 
 
(iii)  Rural  social  safety  net.  This  component  will  focus  on  designing  and 
establishing a rural social safety net. The aim will be to ensure a minimum living 
standard for the destitute rural poor who lack productive capacity, such as the 
childless elderly households, disabled, and female-headed households. Although 
these groups comprise a growing share of the rural poor, the Government’s 
development-based poverty reduction programs do not address their needs well. 
(ADB Financing: $50,000; Consulting Services: 3 person-months; Time Frame: 
August–December 2006) 
 
8.  Future areas to be covered under the TA will  include policy and institutional reforms 
such as environment improvement, promotion of resource saving economy, rule of law, and 
good governance,  which respond to emerging real-time needs of the Government. In these 
areas, ADB’s involvement is expected top roduce notable policy and capacity building impacts 
to enhance ADB operations, including monitoring its portfolio’s contribution to CSP outcomes. 
The impacts include formulation and/or amendment of policies, laws, regulations, and design of

institutional structure, operational procedures, and capacity building mechanisms. Institutional 
reforms will mi prove efficiency in public services, while capacity building will enhance the 
Government’s  understanding  of  ADB’s  new  Innovation  and  Efficiency  Initiatio nA.dditional 
components  will  be  identified  during  the  two-year  TA  implementation  period  according  to 
selection criteria stipulated in para. 10 below.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  The TA will allow ADB to provide quick support to PRC’s reform and capacity building 
efforts, which  will have strong result-orientation through specific advice in key priority areas 
where the Government is looking for suggestions and support.The flexible design will allow the 
selection of some topics during TA implementation, based on the following criteria: (i) topics 
must be consistent with the reform agenda set out in the CSP of the PRC, and fall under the 
strategic focus areas of ADB’s operatiosn in  the PRC; (ii) the  Government must accord the 
policy reform a high priority; and (iii) a small amount of strategic assistance must be able to help 
advance the reform agenda. No components should be used for project preparation.  Their 
impact on ADB’s portfolio and project management will determine the eslection of capacity 
building components. ADB staff will monitor the TA progress and outputs closely, and discuss 
the policy with relevant Government agencies. 
 
10.  For each component, conferences and workshops will be  held to discuss the issues, 
build  consensus,  and  disseminate  information.  During  the  conferences  and  workshops, 
intensive consultations will be conducted between staff of EAs and IAs, and international and 
domestic officials. The participants might come from the relevant Government agencies, private 
sector,  nongovernment  organizations,  and  external  funding  agencies.  The  assistance  will 
include information dissemination mechanisms in English and Chinese. The outputs will be 
published on the ADB Web site and in hardcopy format. When needed, press conferences will 
be held. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
11.   The TA is estimated to cost $680,000 equivalent. The Government has asked ADB to 
finance $500,000 equivalent on a grant basis from ADB's TA funding program. The Government 
will finance the balance of the cost, equivalent to $180,000, through the provision of office space, 
counterpart staff, honorarium, and other miscellaneous services. Of the identified components, 
the local government debt component is estimated  to cost $100,000,  while the  other  two 
components  are  expected  to  cost  $50,000  each.  Appendix  2  has  the  details  of  the  cost 
estimates and the financing plan. 
 
12.  The cost estimate is based on engaging eight international experts as resource persons 
for 2 person-months, 10 domestic experts as resource persons for 2 person-months, and nine 
individual  consultants  for  20  person-months.  The  resource  persons  mainly  will  share 
international experience and practices, which will be limited to  the short term. The resource 
persons and individual consultants will be selected and engaged in accordance with the ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the 
engagement  of  domestic  consultants. To facilitate seminars and conferences, an advance 
payment facility can be provided to the IAs.

5
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  As the EA  for  the TA,  MOF will  be responsible for  coordinating  and implementing 
relevant activities. The  IAs for  each component will depend on the topics. The IAs for the 
identified  components  include:  (i)  MOF’s Budget  Department  for  local  government  debt 
component; (ii) MOF’sI nternational Department for the portfolio management component; and 
(iii)  Ministry  of  Civil  Affairs  for  the  rural  safety  net  component.  Potential  IAs should be 
government agencies and government-owned or -controlled entities that are able to prepare a 
clear proposal, and have sufficient staff capacity and office space to implement the TA.  
 
14.  The  Government  will  participate  actively  in  topic  selection,  assistance  design,  and 
implementation. Potential IAs should send future proposals for candidate components to MOF. 
The PRCM and MOF jointly will select future components that are high on the Government’s 
agenda and  fall under the strategic focus areas of ADB’s operations in the PRC. The TA is 
expected to begin in June 2006, and be completed by June 2008. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
15.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of  the People’s Republico f China for the Facility for Reform Support and 
Capacity Building, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

BACKGROUND OF THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE COMPONENTS AND  
GENERIC TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
A.  Local Government Debt 
1.  Background Information 
1.  Local governments in the People’s Republic of China (PRC) are forbidden from issuing 
debt. The central Government wants to maintain prudent debt management, and is concerned 
that  local  governments’  issuance  of  debt  might  disturb  local  financial  stability  and  local 
economic  development.  However,  taxes  and  other  revenues  are  inadequate  for  local 
governments to maintain rapid economic growth. As a result, many local governments have to 
go around the central Government regulations and carry debt in many forms, including implied 
guarantees for loans of local government-owned enterprises, auction of state assets, etc. While 
these hidden debts are difficult to discern and calculate, they could pose major problems to the 
financial status of local governments. 
 
2.  The PRC and the international community have become increasingly concerned about 
local  government  debt  issues.  However,  conducting  systematic,  in-depth,  and  practically 
valuable research in the area is fairly difficult, because local government debt is forbidden and 
local governments are sensitive about the topic.  
 
3.  Nevertheless,  the  establishment  of  a  legal  and  regulatory  framework  for  local 
government  debt  is  important  to  enhance  governance  and  risk  management  of  local 
governments. This will  allow the issuance and management of local government debt to be 
regulated, thereby preventing or controlling local government debt risks. To achieve this, the 
Budget  Department  of  the  Ministry  of  Finance  (MOF)  urgently  needs  to  analyze  laws, 
regulations, and operational procedures of selected countries. Further, it must make preliminary 
recommendations on laws, regulations, and other technical issues, including the accounting and 
reporting system, information system, and early warning system. These counties could include 
Australia, Japan, New Zealand, South Africa, and the United States. 
 
2.  Generic Terms of Reference for Consultants 
4.  This  component  will  require  the  recruitment  of  one  domestic  government  debt 
management specialist (3 person-months) and one fiscal risk management specialist (2 person-
months) to prepare a report on local government debt management. The government debt 
management specialist will be responsible for the legal and regulatory framework of the report. 
The  fiscal  risk  management  specialist  will  be  responsible  for  the  accounting,  reporting, 
information, and early warning systems aspects of the report. The report will compile information 
on local government debt management in selected countries identified by MOF. The consultants 
also will provide logistical support to the Implementing Agency (IA) in organizing workshops and 
conferences. 
 
5.  Three international resource persons (around 7 days each) will be invited to share their 
international experiences and best practices of local government debt management.

B.  Portfolio Management Training for Asian Development Bank (ADB) Projects  
1.  Background Information 
6.  As of 2005, ADB’s loan commitmenst to the PRC since the start of operations in 1987 
comprised 115 public sector loans, totaling $16.2 billion, all from the ordinary capital resources 
(OCR). This represents about 14.5% of ADB’s lending to its developing member countries 
(DMC) since ADB was established. ADB has lent on average more than $1 billion per year to 
the PRC since 1993, including $1.46 billion in 2005. The PRC portfolio has been one of the best 
among ADB’s DMCs. The number of at-risk projects is below the ADB average, and a majority 
of continuing projects are rated satisfactory in ADB’sp roject performance report system. Project 
completion reports and  project performance evaluation reports have rated most completed 
projects as successful. 
 
7.  However, the performance can be improved. Country portfolio reviews (CPR) identified 
key portfolio issues, and recommended actions to improve portfolio performance. These issues 
included (i) start-up delays, (ii) slow disbursement for some projects, (iii) difficulties by the 
executing agencies (EA) in complying with loan financial covenants, and (iv) extensions of loan 
closing dates. 
 
8.  In addition, the profile of the portfolio is expected to change significantly within next three 
years. While transport projects still will dominate ADB’s operations int he PRC, the share of the 
agriculture  and  natural  resources  sector  and  the  social sector will increase substantially. 
Meanwhile, sector lending, multi-tranche financing facilities, and similar modalities will be used 
increasingly for new projects, which might  include some small projects. More far-reaching 
changes  are  also  likely  under  the  Partnership  Framework  with  Middle  Income  and  OCR 
Countries. These changes would improve future project implementation. ADB has taken some 
initiatives to increase the  flexibility of procurement operations. However, the processing and 
implementation of these projects will involve many stakeholders, who might not have  been 
involved in ADB operations. Considering the issues in project implementation, as well as the 
changing context and shift in operational strategy, ADB’s PRC portfolio needs to be reviewed, 
the  key  constrains  on  project  processing  and  implementation  analyzed,  and  measures  to 
effectively facilitate project formulation and implementation recommended.  
 
2.  Generic Terms of Reference for Consultants 
9.  Two  domestic  consultants  will  be  engaged  for  a  total  of  5  person-months.  One 
consultant will be responsible for a study on effective project implementation. Specifically, the 
study will examine the participation of EAs and IAs in all project cycles. The consultant will 
review the implementation arrangements of ADB-financed PRC projects in each sector. The 
effectiveness of these implementation arrangements then will be assessed based on the review, 
and major constraints and issues that impede smooth project implementation will be identified. 
The study will look into options to strengthen EAs’  and IAs’  ownershipf  tohe implementation 
arrangements.  Further,  it  will  examine  options  for  their  proactive  participation  in  project 
formulation, implementation, and operation. This task will take 3 months, starting in April 2006. 
 
10.  The other consultant will conduct  a  comprehensive  review  on  ADB’s PRC portfolio 
performance, including approaches to correlate  the portfolio performance contribution to the 
country strategy and  program (CSP) outcomes. The consultant will  review thoroughly the 
portfolio, and identify key portfolio performance issues that need to be addressed to improve 
performance. Based on this review, the consultant will recommend key actions to be taken by

and to contribute effectively to CSP outcomes. This task will take 2 months, beginning in July

11.   Both consultants should have in-depth knowledge of  ADB project cycle, safeguard 
policies, thematic priorities, and sector policies.  In addition, the consultants should be fully 
aware  of  Government  approval  procedures  for  project  development,  and  Government 
administrative framework for project implementation. 
 
C.  Rural Social Safety Net  
1.  Background Information 
12.   The PRC has made remarkable progress in reducing poverty, cutting the number of 
rural people living in absolute poverty6 from roughly 250 million in 1978 to an estimated 26.1 
million in 2004.  Despite the Government’s expanding efforts and increasing investment, the 
poverty reduction in the PRC has decelerated. This reflects, in part, the shifting nature of 
poverty in the PRC, which increasingly is concentrated  in remote communities and hard-to-
reach groups, such as the elderly and disabled who lack productive capacity. While these 
groups comprise a growing share of the absolute poor rural population, the Government’s 
development-based poverty reduction programs—premised on lifting the poor out of poverty by 
enhancing opportunities for improved productivity and work income—do not address their needs 
well.  
 
13.  Within the Government, the consensus is growing on the need to establish viable rural 
minimum living standards schemes (MLSS) capable of meeting the needs of the poorest of the 
poor who lack productive capacity. This consensus is rooted in international experiences and in 
the PRC’st rack record in implementing urban MLSS to address urban poverty, which fall under 
the Ministry of Civil Affairs (MOCA). As reflected in recommendations released by the Central 
Communist Party to guide the drafting of the PRC’s1 1th Five-Year Program for Economic and 
Social Development (2006–2010), the construction of such a rural system will be a priority. This 
new direction is consistent with—and appears to have been partly catalyzed by—recent policy 
advocacy by ADB. The MLSS component  of the technical assistance  also builds on ADB’s 
cooperation with MOCA under Facility for Policy Reform Support (TA4365) in taking stock and 
conducting  a  preliminary  assessment  of  early  efforts  to  pilot  test  rural  MLSS  in  several 
provinces.    
 
2.  Generic Terms of Reference for Consultants 
14.  One domestic expert on MLSS will be hired for 3 person-months to coordinate inputs 
from four resource persons spanning related areas of expertise, including indicatively income 
and  non-income  poverty,  poverty  targeting,  financing,  and  institutional  assessment  at 
subnational  levels.  One  international  resource  person  (10  days  of  inputs)  will provide a 
summary report on international experiences and best practices in MLSS systems, emphasizing 
relevance to the PRC context.   
 
15.  In close dialogue with ADB and MOCA, the expert and resource person will prepare a 
background study and presentations for a forum on rural MLSS in the PRC, including core 
                                                 
6  This figure refers to the official annual per capita income line of CNY668 in 2004, which is low by international 
standards.

12 Appendix 3 
 
content of a concrete and viable framework for instituting a rural MLSS system. This will be 
based on policy dialogue with MOF and other relevant ministries and agencies at the national 
and  subnational  levels,  including  analysis  of  issues  related  to  vertical  and  horizontal 
coordination. The framework also should present links to additional pro-poor interventions, such 
as existing rural poverty reduction and development programs, education, and health care. The 
expert will be responsible for delivering the final framework of policy and (as appropriate) 
institutional reforms, integrating refinements from  the review at the conference.  The expert 
should possess strong communication skills, and experience in high-level policy dialogue.
